BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: ⚠ Error: Incomplete joker sentence
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: From last Thursday to Tuesday morning, 80-110 cm of snow in the southern Dolomites at 2000 m, 60-80 cm in the northern ones, 80-100 cm in the Vicenza Pre-Alps at 1600 m and 40-70 in the Verona and Belluno areas. The snow/rain limit, initially even at 600 m, then rose with rain on snow even above 1200 m elevation. The activity spontaneous avalanche is expected to be most frequent between 2000 and 1500 m altitude in Agordino, Ampezzano, Arsiero and Recoaro where fresh snowfall contributions have have been greatest. Frequent skidding avalanches are also to be expected along the steep southern grassy slopes below 1,800 m elevation.Detachments caused by slab avalanches may occur already with weak overload.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: From Tuesday afternoon to Thursday, 25-40 cm are still expected at 2000 m in the Dolomites with snow/rain limits rising from 1200 to 1700 m and as much as 60 cm in the Pre-Alps, with snow/rain limits reaching 1700-1900 m i elevation. Avalanche releases will be more likely between 2200 and 1800 m altitude also due to the possible presence of moist surface snow and, may arrive locally and along known routes, at low altitudes. In some areas, expected avalanches may widely affect man-made areas even at sites not usually exposed to avalanche danger. These are medium to high magnitude events. Conditions for hiking and snow descents are critical. People are urged to stay in open trails and to rely on mountain professionals for open field hiking. Visibility will be reduced with the added difficulty of spotting hazardous areas.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and gliding snow require caution. As a consequence of the snowfall the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. Transportation routes situated at higher altitudes can be endangered in some localities in the regions with a lot of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow will fall. The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow significantly. As the snowfall level rises dry and moist avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be very large. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 1800 m. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind and new snow at low altitude. 60 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. As a consequence of snowfall and the strong wind, the snow drift accumulations will increase in size. The snowpack will become increasingly unstable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of the snowfall the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Natural avalanches are possible, even large ones. In steep gullies in the regions with a lot of snow the avalanches can reach intermediate altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches very easily. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in steep terrain above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are numerous and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Gradual increase in avalanche danger as the snowfall level rises.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are very prone to triggering in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual stabilisation of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Residual weak rainfall, waning during the morning. Snow level between 1800 and 2000 metres. New accumulations expected around 5 cm in the Eastern Prealps, lower elsewhere.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new residual precipitation (snow mixed with rain up to 2000 m) will increase and overload the significant layer of recent snow that has not yet consolidated; the threat rating will remain 4 Strong. Triggering will be possible with low overload on many steep slopes at all aspects. To the south the whole recent snow cover rests, almost entirely, on unfrozen uncovered ground, a condition that will favor it accentuated snow flow phenomena. Numerous natural avalanches both on the ground and on the ground will be possible surface, large and very large in size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: From a snowological point of view, the situation will always have to be carefully evaluated, especially in alpine terrain (beyond treeline), and in the central-southern sectors due to rising temperatures. In detail: on the Rhaetian sectors and Adamello the trend in the degree of danger will gradually decrease, going from 4 strong to 3 marked. Problems windy snow above 2300 m, with the presence of extensive soft accumulations, fragilely anchored to the basal layers. About Orobie e Prealpi the avalanche danger level will remain 4 strong. This will be due to the greater accumulations of new snow, compared to northern band, and to the temperature trend, which will determine, in the last tail of the disturbance, rain up to 1800-2000 m (with relative moistening and weakening of the snow). The mild temperatures and the persistence of cloud cover will hinder night-time freezing, further weighing down the snow cover. These sectors will be widely affected by neviflow phenomena (downhill sliding of the entire thickness of the mantle, commonly known as "glide").

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind there will be a rapid increase in the avalanche danger. Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, heavy snowfall and the moderate easterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and in the vicinity of peaks. They are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
Numerous medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. In particular from starting zones at higher altitudes large natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way in some cases, must be expected in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 50 cm of snow has fallen since Sunday above approximately 1600 m.
30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Wednesday above approximately 1600 m.
The easterly wind has transported some snow.
The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is favourably layered. A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Little snow will fall on Thursday. The danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Transportation routes situated at higher altitudes can be endangered in some localities in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. The wind will be moderate to strong.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects and generally above the tree line. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
As a consequence of the snowfall dry avalanches are to be expected, even very large ones.
It is inadvisable to engage in ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind and new snow at low altitude. 30 to 50 cm of snow, and up to 60 cm in some localities, has fallen. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be a gradual increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
As a consequence of the precipitation the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area snowfall. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In all aspects large to very large avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. In addition the barely recognisable wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow as well as the large wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. Weak layers exist in the snowpack. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be partly cloudy.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. Backcountry touring calls for great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Natural avalanches are possible, even large ones. In steep gullies in the regions with a lot of snow the avalanches can reach intermediate altitudes. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches very easily. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in steep terrain above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, as well as at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain in particular at high altitude. The avalanche prone locations are numerous and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.
Gradual increase in avalanche danger as the snowfall level rises.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 60 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are very prone to triggering in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual stabilisation of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, snowfall and the moderate easterly wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop.
The wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant,, also on steep slopes. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
Dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. These weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers.
In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high) avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large in isolated cases. They can be released naturally and can reach as far as intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday above approximately 1600 m.
20 to 40 cm of snow will fall until Wednesday above approximately 1600 m.
The easterly wind has transported the new snow. The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
A lot of snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall on Thursday. The danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Residual weak rainfall, waning during the morning. Snow level between 1800 and 2000 metres. New accumulations of a few centimeters.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new weak snowfall will increase the recent widespread accumulations which will present a weak consolidation on many steep slopes. The triggering will be possible even with a low overload, generating very large avalanches. Numerous large spontaneous releases will be possible on steep slopes not yet released.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: From a snowological point of view, the situation will always have to be carefully evaluated, especially in alpine terrain (beyond treeline), and in the central-southern sectors due to rising temperatures. In detail: on the Rhaetian sectors and Adamello the trend in the degree of danger will gradually decrease, going from 4 strong to 3 marked. Problems windy snow above 2300 m, with the presence of extensive soft accumulations, fragilely anchored to the basal layers. About Orobie e Prealpi the avalanche danger level will remain 4 strong. This will be due to the greater accumulations of new snow, compared to northern band, and to the temperature trend, which will determine, in the last tail of the disturbance, rain up to 1800-2000 m (with relative moistening and weakening of the snow). The mild temperatures and the persistence of cloud cover will hinder night-time freezing, further weighing down the snow cover. These sectors will be widely affected by neviflow phenomena (downhill sliding of the entire thickness of the mantle, commonly known as "glide").

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow and the wind slabs represent the main danger. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of, snowfall and the moderate easterly wind, a precarious avalanche situation will develop on Wednesday.
These weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the near-surface layers in all aspects.
The cold fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant, especially on steep slopes.
Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
Natural avalanches:
Dry loose snow avalanches and dry slab avalanches are likely to occur, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially on steep slopes.
Dry and moist avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. They can be triggered in the new snow and wind slab layers and can reach as far as the valley bottom.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Sunday.
5 to 15 cm of snow will fall until Wednesday above approximately 1500 m.
The easterly wind has transported some snow. The fresh snow and the wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
The wind slabs of the weekend are covered with new snow and therefore barely recognisable.
Monday: Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches have been released adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects. Since Friday in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain many small and medium-sized avalanches were released.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Little snow will fall on Thursday. The danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the often large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be moderate to strong in the vicinity of peaks.
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all altitude zones. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation dry and moist avalanches are possible, but they can be large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1600 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the soft surface of an old snowpack. Faceted weak layers exist in the old snowpack on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Precipitation running out.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The phases of snow mixed with rain will weigh down the snowpack, resting on unfrozen exposed ground. On the steep slopes at higher altitudes, releases and spontaneous releases of medium and large ground avalanches will be possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: From a snowological point of view, the situation will always have to be carefully evaluated, especially in alpine terrain (beyond treeline), and in the central-southern sectors due to rising temperatures. In detail: on the Rhaetian sectors and Adamello the trend in the degree of danger will gradually decrease, going from 4 strong to 3 marked. Problems windy snow above 2300 m, with the presence of extensive soft accumulations, fragilely anchored to the basal layers. About Orobie e Prealpi the avalanche danger level will remain 4 strong. This will be due to the greater accumulations of new snow, compared to northern band, and to the temperature trend, which will determine, in the last tail of the disturbance, rain up to 1800-2000 m (with relative moistening and weakening of the snow). The mild temperatures and the persistence of cloud cover will hinder night-time freezing, further weighing down the snow cover. These sectors will be widely affected by neviflow phenomena (downhill sliding of the entire thickness of the mantle, commonly known as "glide").

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Weakly bonded old snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above the tree line. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases even by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more frequent small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Tuesday. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs have increased in size appreciably. They are prone to triggering.

Avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The high humditiy will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area snowfall. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. In addition the barely recognisable wind slabs should be taken into account. These have formed in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh snow as well as the large wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. Weak layers exist in the snowpack. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be partly cloudy.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above the tree line. Very isolated natural avalanches are possible, especially in the Ultental and in the Ortler Range. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can still be released in isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation small to medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more frequent medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Tuesday. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs have increased in size appreciably, in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. They are prone to triggering.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines. This applies especially on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches, including medium-sized ones. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

Avalanches can in isolated cases be triggered in the old snowpack and reach large size in isolated cases in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found above approximately 2400 m.

As a consequence of warming during the day individual loose snow slides are to be expected as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small. On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 5 to 15 cm of snow fell on Tuesday. The southerly wind has transported the new snow. Fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers especially on shady slopes.

In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on shady slopes above the tree line. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places even by individual winter sport participants. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on west, north and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation mostly small loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more frequent small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow fell on Tuesday. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs have increased in size moderately. They are in some cases prone to triggering.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist deeper in the snowpack in particular on steep east, north and west facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a gradual stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Precipitation running out.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thin layers of snow resting on uncovered ground. Possible discharges of small and medium size on steep slopes at higher altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: From a snowological point of view, the situation will always have to be carefully evaluated, especially in alpine terrain (beyond treeline), and in the central-southern sectors due to rising temperatures. In detail: on the Rhaetian sectors and Adamello the trend in the degree of danger will gradually decrease, going from 4 strong to 3 marked. Problems windy snow above 2300 m, with the presence of extensive soft accumulations, fragilely anchored to the basal layers. About Orobie e Prealpi the avalanche danger level will remain 4 strong. This will be due to the greater accumulations of new snow, compared to northern band, and to the temperature trend, which will determine, in the last tail of the disturbance, rain up to 1800-2000 m (with relative moistening and weakening of the snow). The mild temperatures and the persistence of cloud cover will hinder night-time freezing, further weighing down the snow cover. These sectors will be widely affected by neviflow phenomena (downhill sliding of the entire thickness of the mantle, commonly known as "glide").

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. In addition individual gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on steep shady slopes above the tree line, caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. Mostly avalanches are only small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Tuesday. As a consequence of the strong wind the wind slabs have increased in size moderately. They are in isolated cases prone to triggering.

In particular in the south only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The conditions will facilitate a stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations. The high humditiy will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack also at elevated altitudes. Moist snow slides are to be expected.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Small avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. At high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. Some new snow above approximately 1700 m.
